title: Chorizo Mexicano
ingredients: 1½ pounds lean boneless pork shoulder, coarsely ground
8 ounces pork fat (you might get most by rendering the fat from the pork shoulder)
12 medium (about 6 ounces total) dried ancho chiles, stemmed and seeded
1½ teaspoons cinnamon (preferably freshly ground Mexican canela)
1 tablespoon EACH fresh thyme leaves and marjoram leaves;
or, 1 teaspoon EACH dried thyme and marjoram
instructions: Tear the chiles into flat pieces and toast them in a heavy skillet or on a griddle heated over medium heat, pressing them flat with a metal spatula until they are aromatic, about 10 seconds per side.  In a bowl, rehydrate the chiles for 20 minutes in hot water.  Cover the chiles with hot water then place a small plate on top to keep the chiles submerged.  After 20 minutes drain and transfer the chili pieces to a food processor or blender.

Pulverize the bay leaves in a mortar or a spice grinder, then add to the food processor along with the cinnamon, cloves, oregano, thyme and marjoram and 1½ teaspoons salt.  Measure in the vinegar and 2 tablespoons of water process until mixture is smooth, adding a little more water if necessary to keep everything moving through the blades.  Press the mixture through a medium-mesh sieve into a large bowl.

Place the ground pork in a large bowl and add the chili and seasoning mixture.  Mix thoroughly.  It’s best to cover and refrigerate the chorizo overnight for the flavors to meld.  The next day fry a little portion of the chorizo and taste it for salt and adjust the salt content if necessary.
remarks: Refrigerated, the chorizo keeps for about a week, however, frozen it will keep much longer.
yield: Make about 2½ pounds of fresh sausage.
source: Mexico One Plate at a Time by Rick Bayless, Scribner, 1230 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10020, ©2000 by Rick Bayless.
